How do you determine if a statement is a tautology or not, based on its truth table?
A statement is a tautology if it is always true, regardless of the truth values of its components (A and B).

Tautology          A B (A v B⊃ (A ⋅ B) T T        T    T    T T F        T    F    F F T        T    F    F F F        F    T    F A B (~A ⊃ ~B) ⊃ (~B ⊃ ~A) T T        T    T    T T F        T    F    F F T        F    T    T F F        T    T    T A B (A ⊃ B) ⊃ (~B ⊃ ~A) T T        T    T    T T F        F    T    F F T        T    T    T F F        T    T    T A B (B v ~B) ⊃ A T T           T   T T F           T   T F T           T   F F F           T   F A B (A v B) v ~A T T           T  T  F T F           T  T  F F T           T  T  T F F           F  T  T Answers to exercises  222 Exercise 16 1.
Introduction to Logic and Critical Thinking, by Matthew Van Cleave
